item.title: [HBASE-11497] Expose RpcScheduling implementations as LimitedPrivate interfaces
item.description:
In PHOENIX-938 we are attempting to resolve cross-RS deadlocks in indexing by adding custom RPC handlers (so regular puts/reads don't interfere with index updates). However, we've run into a couple of snags where the interfaces change, making it a bit more difficult to support interoperability between minor versions as the underlying RPC handling changed (for the better, but still different .

This would just mark those interfaces Public, Evolving, so we still have some flexibility, but don't break existing usage.

Note, this kind of thing will come up for any client who is doing custom RPC handling - beyond the recently added flexibility - but wants to stay in line with the current HBase implementation (rather than building their own RPC handling mechanisms).

comments.comment: For right now, I'm thinking we need to expose SimpleRpcScheduler as well as RpcExecutor and its subclasses.

I would refrain from adding InterfaceAudience.Public to the RPC handler interfaces. Regular clients are not going to implement / use those. It seems like a LimitedPrivate with either Coprocessors or similar audience would be a better target.

It seems like a LimitedPrivate with either Coprocessors or similar audience would be a better target.


@InterfaceAudience.LimitedPrivate({"Coprocessor","Phoenix"})

could work as long as the RM checks with the designated users. For 0.98 I can definitely do that. What do you think Jesse Yates?
That seems reasonable. I'll put together a patch
This labels the classes you would need to custom implement RPC handling and exposes the elements you would need (from default -> public).
+1 for 0.98 and trunk, ping Enis Soztutar for branch-1

Does the InterfaceAudience means that you not only have to preserve the public methods but also the "open" methods/members of the class?

e.g. With the latest changes SimpleRPCScheduler has not changed the public interface (all the methods aside 1 private are still there), but the 3 queues that were open at the package level were removed.


 -  final BlockingQueue<CallRunner> callQueue;

 -  final BlockingQueue<CallRunner> priorityCallQueue;

 -  final BlockingQueue<CallRunner> replicationQueue;

Does the InterfaceAudience means that you not only have to preserve the public methods but also the "open" methods/members of the class?

I would not think *Interface*Audience covers members. A Java interface can contain only constants, method signatures, and nested types. However this is surely up for interpretation. Maybe we can adopt a stance that audience tags for interfaces define the term as Java does (which is logical IMO) and document it somewhere in the refguide.

Edit: Additionally, wherever we are directly referring to members of super classes that have a public audience, we should add a public getter. Shall I open a JIRA for that?

Assuming Jesse Yates is a +1.

Going to commit this to 0.98+ tomorrow, leaving until then for additional comment or NACK
